overview_of_class: This course will focus on some major works and important genres of literature produced during the 17th and 18th centuries: we will read three plays, a short novel, and a philosophical essay, with a view to understanding the development of literary forms and ideas from the 17th century to the Enlightenment. A particular focus will be the critique of the social model based on a refined court culture in the 17th century and the gradual evolution of society towards a more open, egalitarian culture in the 18th century. In addition we will read short excerpts from other major authors of the period, and short modern descriptions of court society.
name: Classicism and Enlightenment
title: WCAS FRENCH 312-0-20 Classicism and Enlightenment

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value:
These are the class attributes listed for this class:
Literature & Fine Arts

Prerequisite: 271, 272, 273 or consent of instructor

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Students will be evaluated on their participation in discussions, prepared oral reports, and three papers. The final paper will be a longer comparative paper. The course is conducted entirely in French.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Racine, Britannicus
Molière, Le Misanthrope
Voltaire, L'Ingénu
Rousseau, Discours sur les sciences et les arts
Beaumarchais, Le Mariage de Figaro

Additional materials will be available in a course packet. There will be some excerpts describing court society; for the 17th century, materials will include some Fables by La Fontaine, and selected texts from La Bruyère's Caractères and La Rochefoucauld's Maximes; for the 18th century, passages from Montesquieu's L'Esprit des Lois and Voltaire's Lettres philosophiques.
